title: Cognitive Appraisal Theory
body: From Nussbaum's Upheavals of Thought in philosophy, emotions are evaluative judgments. Field: philosophy
definition: Emotions are evaluative judgments assessing events or objects as significant relative to personal well-being.
measurement: NLP sentiment analysis; scenario-based evaluation; qualitative interpretation tasks.

title: Physiological Theory of Emotion
body: Classical physiological theory holds that emotions arise from bodily perceptions. Field: philosophy
definition: Emotions are perceptions of bodily states or physiological responses triggered by stimuli.
measurement: Facial emotion recognition accuracy using FER-2013 dataset; voice tone analysis and biometric monitoring (heart rate, skin conductance sensors).

title: Phenomenological Aspect of Emotion
body: Goldie's philosophical work explores the subjective experience of emotion. Field: philosophy
definition: The subjective, experiential, qualitative aspect of emotional experience.
measurement: User-reported surveys assessing emotional authenticity; qualitative user interviews exploring subjective emotional experiences; interpretative phenomenological analysis (IPA).

title: Somatic Marker Hypothesis
body: Damasio's neuroscience research links emotion and cognition through bodily states. Field: neuroscience
definition: Emotional processes guide or bias behavior and decision-making through bodily states and sensations.
measurement: Behavioral decision-making tasks; physiological response monitoring; computational models using reinforcement learning informed by somatic marker frameworks.

title: Artificial Moral Agency
body: Floridi and Sanders discuss AI as morally accountable agents in philosophy and ethics. Field: philosophy
definition: AI systems can perform actions with moral significance, raising questions of moral responsibility.
measurement: Moral decision-making scenario tests (e.g., trolley dilemmas adapted for AI); moral Turing tests; simulations of moral dilemmas.

title: Ethical AI Development
body: Coeckelbergh's AI Ethics emphasizes ethical obligations in emotion recognition technologies. Field: philosophy
definition: Normative principles guiding fair, responsible, and inclusive development of emotional AI.
measurement: Algorithmic fairness assessments using frameworks such as statistical parity and equalized odds; inclusivity audits; ethical impact assessments.

title: Ethical Framework for Emotional AI
body: Boddington proposes normative guidelines for emotional AI engagement. Field: philosophy
definition: Normative principles for how emotional AI should interact with people.
measurement: Compliance audits and social impact assessments.

title: Sympathy and Moral Sentiment
body: Classical moral philosophy highlights ethical empathy in emotional judgment. Field: philosophy
definition: Capacity for emotional understanding and compassionate response towards others’ emotional states.
measurement: Empathy and sympathy scenario evaluations; user feedback; compassionate response accuracy tests.

title: Bias and Power Dynamics
body: Crawford critiques bias in emotion recognition algorithms in the field of technology ethics. Field: philosophy
definition: Exploration of systemic bias, ethical fairness, and power inequalities embedded in AI systems, particularly emotion recognition.
measurement: Demographic bias testing in datasets; fairness metrics applied to emotional recognition datasets (AffectNet, IEMOCAP); power dynamics evaluations.

title: Emotion Regulation
body: Gross's psychological research examines how people adjust emotional responses. Field: psychology
definition: The processes by which individuals or systems influence which emotions they experience, when, and how they express them.
measurement: Emotional response modulation tasks; interaction scenarios; observational methods and sentiment analysis.

title: Theory of Mind
body: Baron-Cohen and colleagues explore attribution of mental states and emotions. Field: psychology
definition: Ability to attribute mental states (beliefs, desires, intentions) to others.
measurement: False-belief tasks adapted for AI; predictive accuracy tests; interpretability analysis.

title: Basic Emotions Model
body: Ekman's work identifies universal emotional expressions studied in psychology. Field: psychology
definition: Proposes universal discrete emotions with characteristic expressions.
measurement: Facial Action Coding System and cross-cultural expression recognition.

title: Multimodal Emotion Recognition
body: Poria and colleagues describe algorithms that combine audio, visual, and text cues. Field: computer science
definition: Algorithms integrating multiple modalities (audio, visual, textual) for emotion detection.
measurement: Accuracy metrics from multimodal datasets; model interpretability tests.

title: Affective Computing
body: Picard's foundational computer science book introduces computational methods for interpreting and simulating emotion. Field: computer science
definition: Computational systems that recognize, interpret, or simulate emotions.
measurement: Emotion classification accuracy and user interaction studies.

title: Neural Circuits of Emotion
body: LeDoux describes amygdala and limbic roles in emotion processing from neuroscience. Field: neuroscience
definition: Brain structures and pathways involved in emotional processing such as the amygdala and prefrontal cortex.
measurement: Neurological modeling; fMRI correlation methods; computational simulations.

title: Primary Emotional Systems
body: Panksepp identifies fundamental emotional circuits such as SEEKING and FEAR. Field: neuroscience
definition: Basic neural systems such as SEEKING and FEAR underlying emotions.
measurement: Animal models and neurochemical manipulations.

title: Facial Expression Recognition
body: Adolphs analyzes neural mechanisms for detecting facial expressions. Field: neuroscience
definition: Neural mechanisms for perceiving facial expressions of emotion.
measurement: Behavioral recognition tasks and neuroimaging.

title: Core Affect Model
body: Russell's psychological construction approach views emotions as constructed from affective dimensions. Field: psychology
definition: Emotions constructed from valence and arousal dimensions of core affect.
measurement: Affect Grid ratings and physiological indicators of valence/arousal.

title: Action Readiness
body: Frijda defines emotion as states preparing action, influencing adaptation. Field: psychology
definition: Emotions prepare action tendencies in response to situations.
measurement: Behavior observation and self-reported motivational states.

title: Embodied Cognition and Emotion
body: Clark's work on embodied cognition links emotional interactions to the situated body. Field: philosophy
definition: Emotion is intrinsically tied to physical states and situational contexts.
measurement: Embodied interaction scenarios involving embodied AI platforms (e.g., Pepper Robot, virtual reality environments); situated emotional responses; dynamic contextual adaptations.
